{{about|music played in {{MC}}|the command|Commands/music|other uses|Music (disambiguation)}}
''Minecraft'' contains many '''music''' tracks, which play in various places in the game, including on the [[Title Screen|main menu]], in [[Creative]] mode, in [[the Nether]], in [[the End]], and during the [[Credit sequence|credits]]. The music tracks in the game are composed by [[C418]], [[Lena Raine]], [[Kumi Tanioka]], [[Samuel Åberg]], [[Aaron Cherof]], [[Amos Roddy]], and [[Hyper Potions]].

== Playing ==
Music tracks can play at various points during gameplay. Some types of music are triggered by events, while others play randomly while certain criteria are met. The song "Alpha" always plays instantly during the credits, and the song "Boss" always plays instantly while the player is in [[the End]] if the [[ender dragon]] is undefeated or resummoned. Both of these tracks start playing in place of any already playing music. If the player is in the End and the ender dragon has been defeated, the normal End track plays 5 to 20 minutes after any currently playing tracks are finished.

If the player is underwater in an [[ocean]] or [[river]] biome, random underwater tracks play randomly 10 to 20 minutes after any currently playing tracks are finished.<ref name=":1">{{bug|MCPE-76213}}</ref>

If none of the previous criteria are met, but the player is in the Nether, a random general [[Nether]] track or a Nether [[biome]]-specific track plays, except [[warped forest]]s, which don't have any music. If the player is not in the Nether and is currently in [[Creative]] mode{{note|In Java Edition, rather than checking the player's gamemode directly, the game checks for both the <code>instabuild</code> and <code>mayfly</code> [[Player.dat format|player abilities]] and plays Creative music if both are true.<ref><code>1.21.5.jar/net/minecraft/client/Minecraft.java</code> lines 2425-2455: <code>public MusicInfo getSituationalMusic()</code></ref> Both are normally enabled upon entering Creative mode, but can be enabled or disabled individually by third-party means.}}, a random track plays (Creative only on Bedrock). If the player is not in Creative but is currently playing (i.e., not on the menu screen), a random general track plays. These tracks all play 10 to 20 minutes after any currently playing tracks are finished.

If a music track is playing while the player is entering a [[pale garden]], it fades into silence. The music resumes when the player exits the biome.

If the player is on the menu screen, a random menu track starts playing after 1 to 30 seconds.

Menu music stops playing {{in|java}} when the player leaves the [[main menu]] and stops playing {{in|bedrock}} when a loading screen finishes. Game music stops playing when the player quits the world. When the game is paused, game music continues to play {{in|java}}, while {{in|bedrock}} it pauses and resumes when the player exits the pause menu.

Music also stops playing on lagging for a very long time, including under the highly complicated calculations like exploding a lot of [[TNT]] continuously, and when the memory usage is close to the allocation point and do not clear out for many seconds or even minutes.{{verify|Bug report please}}

All music as well as sounds in ''Minecraft'' are stored in the '''sound directory'''. {{IN|je}}, however, the sound files are obfuscated and cannot be directly accessed. To get around with this, the sound directory can be extracted by the methods showed in [[Tutorial:Sound directory]]. {{IN|be}}, the music files are not obfuscated and can be found directly at {{Cd|''game directory''\data\resource_packs\vanilla_music\sounds\music}}.
[[File:Music toast.png|thumb|right|A music toast in ''Java Edition'']]
{{IN|java}}, the player can change how frequently music plays by changing the "Music Frequency" setting in the "Music & Sounds" menu.

{{IN|java}}, when the "Show Music Toast" setting is enabled in the "Music & Sounds" menu, a toast showing the track name and artist appears on-screen when a new track starts playing. This toast is also shown in the [[pause menu]].

== Legacy Console Edition ==
The [[Legacy Console Edition]] versions of the game had a lot of custom music created for its many [[Mash-up pack|Mash-up packs]] and [[mini games]] composed primarily by [[Gareth Coker]], with some earlier [[Mash-up pack]] work<ref>https://twitter.com/4JStudios/status/657528284218052609</ref> and likely early [[Battle mini game]] work{{Note|1=This is not confirmed, although it is very likely that C418 composed the first four default battle tracks as he had collaborated with 4J Studios for the Festive and Halloween Mash Up packs prior to the release of Battle. C418 spoke about a bit about what appears to be his work with 4J Studios with Anthony Fantano.|name=C418 Battle Music Note}}<ref>"10 Years of the Minecraft Soundtrack | C418 INTERVIEW" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4mn47MqhbFY&t=2627s</ref> done by [[C418]].

=== Mash-Up Packs ===
====Festive Mash-Up Pack====
This soundtrack was written by [[C418]] and features tracks from [[Minecraft - Volume Beta]] and Christmas inspired arrangements of other tracks from [[Minecraft - Volume Beta]]. These special arrangements do not appear on an album and do not have names. The tracks for the [[Festive|battle map]] were written by [[Gareth Coker]] and appeared on the ''[[Minecraft: Battle & Tumble (Original Soundtrack)]]'' album. These files are found in <code>DLC/Festive/Data</code>{{Note|Not to be confused with the Festive Skin Pack, which is located at <code>DLC/Festive Skin Pack</code>}}.

====Pirates of the Caribbean Mash-Up Pack====
This original soundtrack was composed by [[Gareth Coker]]{{note|According to the credits data of the pack}} and was inspired by [[wikipedia:Pirates of the Caribbean|Disney's Pirates of the Caribbean franchise]] and its associated film soundtracks. Despite being a licensed mash-up pack, music from the source material was not used. This is the only complete original score written for {{LCE}} that has not been published as an album, and there are no titles for the tracks either. These files are found in <code>DLC/Pirates of the Caribbean/Data</code>.

=== Mini Games ===
The mini games for [[Legacy Console Edition]] also have their own unique soundtracks, composed by [[Gareth Coker]] and [[C418]]{{Note|name=C418 Battle Music Note}}. Each map is assigned a set of music tracks, either by using a [[Mash-up pack|Mash-Up pack]] that supports custom music, or a hardcoded <code>TrackList</code> for packs that don't by using the map's <code>ThemeID</code>. These tracks can be found in the <code>music</code> folder, or <code>audio</code> folder for [[Xbox 360 Edition]] prior to [[TU57]], at the root of the game files. Mini game tracks that are part of a [[Mash-up pack]] can be found inside of the <code>Data</code> folder inside of its respective <code>DLC</code> folder.

==== Tumble ====
These music tracks play in the [[Tumble|Tumble mini game]]. While there were map themes made for special occasions and holidays, there were no unique tracks made for them. If a [[Mash-up pack|Mash-Up pack]] with custom music was used and it lacked Tumble music definition, it would default to using the [[Overworld]] music from that pack. Otherwise the default themes would play.

== Composers ==
Originally, all of ''Minecraft'''s music was composed by [[C418]]. According to Mojang, as the game got more popular (specifically starting with the [[Update Aquatic]]<ref>{{Mcnet|the-sound-scary|The Sound of Scary}}</ref>), others were hired to produce music and soundtracks for the game. However, C418 has cited legal disputes between himself and Microsoft, who wanted to own the music he produced outright, as the real reason for additional composers. Since the [[Nether Update]], new tracks composed by [[Lena Raine]], [[Kumi Tanioka]], [[Samuel Åberg]], [[Aaron Cherof]], [[Amos Roddy]] and [[Hyper Potions]] were added. Samuel Åberg also composed many recent ambient sounds. Original music created for mash-up packs and [[Mini games|Minigames]], created by [[4J Studios]] for [[Legacy Console Edition]], were composed by [[Gareth Coker]].

== History ==
Due to the way assets are downloaded {{in|je}}, changes can be seen in development versions released before the change was made, due to them using the same assets index file.

}}

== Trivia ==
{{split|section=1|reason=a lot of these should be on the individual songs' pages and not here}}
* "The End" is heavily built on modified versions of several tracks from "Minecraft - Volume Alpha".<ref>https://genius.com/C418-the-end-lyrics#about - Genius's description</ref>
* "calm3.ogg", or "Sweden", is a {{W|Passacaglia|newtab=1}}, with a changing melody over a repeated bass line.
* On April Fools' Day 2014, Mojang played a bunch of villager themed pranks on the players, including temporarily replacing the track "hal1.ogg", or "Subwoofer Lullaby", with a version that had a villager singing along, as well as temporarily replacing all the menu songs with the villagers singing the Game Of Thrones theme song. This was reverted on April 2, 2014.
* hal3.ogg (Haggstrom) is in {{W|septuple meter|newtab=1}} (precisely 7/4 time).
* According to C418, the track "Mice on Venus" (game filename is piano3.ogg) was originally a short piano solo, but was then changed later in ''Minecraft's'' development and an addendum was added, which made the track what the game has currently.<ref>{{Cite|url=https://c418.org/albums/minecraft-volume-alpha/|title=Minecraft Volume Alpha|website=C418's Website}}</ref>
* The [[warped forest]] and [[pale garden]] are the only biomes in the game devoid of music, but they accomplish this in different ways.
** The warped forest simply doesn't play music when the game would normally start playing a new track, but any music that started playing before entering a warped forest will continue playing. A sound event does exist for it (named <code>music.nether.warped_forest</code> {{in|JE}} and <code>music.game.warped_forest</code> {{in|BE}}), but it is unused by default.
** The pale garden has special behavior which fades out any currently-playing tracks upon entering the biome. 
* Despite never being implemented, the [[Legacy Console Edition]] code references the cancelled Build Off [[mini game]] with a call for <code>MG04_01.binka</code>. If the game's music player state is modified to be Build Off, the game will actually search for and play the file if it exists.
* [[Music#Overworld music|Overworld music]] does not play in [[Creative|Creative mode]] in [[Legacy Console Edition]].
* Some of the music tracks have a special title:
** The word "Shuniji" (<span lang="ja"><ruby>主虹<rp>, </rp><rt>しゅにじ</rt></ruby></span>) means "primary rainbow" in Japanese.
** The title of the track "So Below" is a reference to "{{W|As above, so below|newtab=1}}"<ref>{{tweet|kuraine|1276983867920941056|Thirdly, it's time to talk about So Below!<br><br>To note, this is not a valley girl re-imagining of the Capy game Below. It's actually half of a motto used in a lot of fun mystical stuff including alchemy, "As above, so below" usually referring to an astral realm or heaven etc.|June 27, 2020|archive=1}}</ref>, a phrase associated with Hermeticism that is derived from a passage from the {{W|Emerald Tablet of Thoth|newtab=1}}, relating to the secrets of creating the {{W|philosopher's stone|newtab=1}}.
** The word ''{{W|rubedo|newtab=1}}'' is Latin for "redness". The term was adopted by alchemists to refer to the final stage of creating the philosopher's stone.<ref>{{Tweet|kuraine|1276237896370909185|Meaning "redness", it signifies the final stage in an alchemical success.|June 25, 2020|archive=1}}</ref>
** The word ''{{W|chrysopoeia|newtab=1}}'' (<span lang="el" dir="ltr">χρυσοποιία</span>) is an alchemical term that describes the creation of the philosopher's stone, or the transmutation of a given object into gold.<ref>{{Tweet|kuraine|1275574918805983232|Chrysopoeia, in alchemy, is the transmutation of something into gold, and the ultimate goal of alchemists.|June 23, 2020|archive=1}}</ref> 
** "Bromeliad" refers to a taxonomic family of flowering plants. This family contains [[pitcher plant]]s and species resembling [[torchflower]]s.
